item.title: Shape Up, basecamp team approach to product development
item.description: Jason Fried let us know Shape Up is available

item.description: 'Beware of shiny new objects' advice by Mark Suster

item.title: Your job is not (only) to write code
item.description: Interesting point of view about improving the product developers work for

item.title: Lessons of Good Design
item.description: What design means to Julie Zhuo

item.title: Basecamp The origin
item.description: To us project management was all about communication. None of the software makers at the time seemed to agree. So we decided to make our own.

item.title: Things learned at Imgur
item.description: A usefull list curated by Sam Gerstenzang about 16 product things he learned at Imgur.

item.title: Choose a license
item.description: A lot of repositories on GitHub.com don't have a license. GitHub provides a license chooser, but if you don't know anything about licenses, how are you supposed to make an informed decision?

item.title: The Red Flags of Hiring
item.description: If you apply to a position, it's important you write an email that feels like a human wrote it and says what you’ve done in as a few words as possible. If you’re looking for a position at a startup, an agency, or something in the online industry, this list of hiring red flags may help you avoid ending up in the immediate ‘no’ pile.

item.title: Android Studio 1.0
item.description: Android Studio 1.0 has been released. Android Studio is the official Integrated Development Environment (IDE) from the Android team.

item.title: Money as a by-product
item.description: About having a side project and turning it into something that is moderately successful; in particular, the challenge of making enough money to sustain the project and perhaps even elevating it from the sidelines so that it becomes something not so on the side at all. ...

item.title: Running a business you worth it
item.description: To be authentic is to be trustworthy. If you’re selling snake oil, or doing Internet Marketing just to make a lot of money, you’re not being authentic. You’re selling something falsely. And people will figure that out, no matter how hard you try. ...
